questions.text: A patient presented with incomplete closure of right eye. On Examination orbicularis oculi weakness was found and cornea had decreased sensation? Which of the following is likely to be associated?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mycobacterium Leprae Given presentation are the ocular manifestation of Leprosy. Common manifestation of ocular leprosy are: LIDS Madarosis Lagophthalmos Nodules Entropion Ectropian Trichiasis Lacrimal System Dacryocystitis Sclera Episcleritis Nodules Staphyloma Cornea Thickened nerves Interstitial keratitis Stromal keratitis corneal Leproma Corneal anesthesia Exposure keratopathy Ciliary body Loss of accommodation Hypotonia Iris Synechiae Iris Pearls Sec. glaucoma Iris atrophy Sec. cataract polycoria Lens Cataract

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Onchocerca volvulus is not usually found in India. Onchocerca volvulus is a filarial nematode that causes onchocerciasis , and is the second-leading cause of blindness due to infection worldwide after trachoma. Extraedge:

Morphology The acid-fast bacilli are arranged singly , in parallel bundles (like rolls of cigarettes in a packet) or in globular masses. The bacilli are slender , slightly curved or straight rods , 1-8 um X 0.2-0.5 um in size. They are Gram positive and acid fast but to a lesser extent than tubercle bacilli. They are aerobic rod shaped. Clinical Features:- It leads to white patches on the skin which arise due to loss of pigmentation from skin. If this disease starts deteriorating , nodes appear on the skin which contains bundles of bacteria , slowly it disseminates into the complete body and causes formation of “granuloma"

questions.text: Punched out lesions in the Fundus are seen in all except :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior Staphyloma Posterior staphyloma is the posterior ectasia of sclera seen in high myopia . It never presents with punched out lesions in the fundus. Posterior staphyloma is considered a hallmark of pathologic myopia and are among one of the major causes of developing maculopathy. However, it can be present in non-myopic eyes, often acquired secondarily due to infection or trauma

Highyeild:

Causes :- Pathological Myopia Posterior Scleritis Perforating Injury Infection Congenital :- Weak Bruch's membrane, Retinitis pigmentosa, Alport syndrome, Pseudoxanthoma elasticum, and Tilted-disc syndrome

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option D - Punched out lesion in toxoplasmosis Option B - Retinal hamartomas are the most common ocular finding in tuberous sclerosis. The majority of hamartomas are non-progressive; however, lesions with subretinal fluid and progression have been reported. Option C - The term is used to describe ocular defects of the eyelids, iris, lens, ciliary body, zonules, choroid, retina or optic nerve . It is typically located in the inferonasal quadrant of the involved structure and is often associated with microphthalmia .

Extraedge:

Some conditions were punched out lesions can be seen are: Tuberous sclerosis Histoplasmosis Toxoplasmosis Sarcoidosis Syphilis Multiple evanescent white dot syndrome Acute posterior placoid pigment epitheliopathy

questions.text: When the patient presents with sudden painful diminision of vision and acute red eye, which of the following has to be taken for consideration ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute Haemorrhagic Conjunctivitis RAPD is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease . Since we are considering Optic neuritis in the patient MRI brain and orbit needs to be done. Anti NMO and anti MOG antibodies: Anti aquaporin-4 antibody is associated with Neuromyelitis optica Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein is associated with multiple sclerosis which is the most common cause of Optic neuritis. Hence Anti NMO and Anti MOG also needs to be done HbA1c Levels are high in anterior ischemic optic neuropathy . It is a biomarker to determine visual prognosis in Optic neuritis. Thyroid function tests are needed to make a diagnosis of exclusion. Causes of Optic neuritis:- ESR Thyroid function test ANA ACE – angiotensin converting enzyme Mitochondrial DNA mutation studies

Highyeild:

Signs Conjunctival congestion Chemosis Multiple hemorrhage in bulbar conjunctiva Mild follicular hyperplasia Lid edema Preauricular lymphadenopathy Corneal sign : fine epithelial keratitis Treatment Broad-spectrum antibiotic eye drop. Usually the disease has a self-limiting course of 7 days.

Option B - Chemical burns are tissue damage caused by strong acids, drain cleaners, paint thinner, gasoline and many other substances . Option C - Bacterial keratitis is an infection of the cornea (the clear dome covering the colored part of the eye) that is caused by bacteria .

Extraedge:

Acute conjunctivitis characterized by multiple conjunctival haemorrhages , conjunctival hyperaemia & mild follicular hyperplasia . Caused by Picornaviruses & transmitted by direct hand to eye contact
